questions.text: A post-renal transplant patient presents with fever and breathlessness. Lung biopsy is done. Which of the following stains is least useful in identifying the causative organism? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congo red

 

Congo red stain is least useful in identifying the causative organism in this post-transplant patient with pneumonia. 

 

Congo red is specifically used to detect amyloid deposits, which show characteristic apple-green birefringence under polarized light. It is not used for identifying infectious organisms. 

 

In the context of a post-renal transplant patient presenting with fever and breathlessness, the most likely diagnosis is Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP), which is a common opportunistic infection in immunocompromised patients. The lung biopsy shows cysts typical of Pneumocystis, which would not be detected by Congo red staining.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Periodic Acid-Schiff (PAS): This is a very useful stain for identifying Pneumocystis jirovecii. PAS stain is excellent for detecting the cyst wall of Pneumocystis organisms and is one of the standard stains used for diagnosing PCP in immunocompromised patients.

 

Option C. Gomori Methenamine Silver (GMS): This is considered the gold standard for staining fungal elements, including Pneumocystis jirovecii. GMS stain clearly demonstrates the characteristic cyst forms of Pneumocystis and is the most commonly used stain for diagnosing PCP.

 

Option D. Fontana-Masson: This stain can be useful for identifying certain organisms, particularly those that are argentophilic (silver-loving). While not specifically for Pneumocystis, it can be used to stain organisms like Cryptococcus and has some utility in identifying certain infectious agents, making it more useful than Congo red in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congo red stain is used specifically for detecting amyloid deposits and is not useful for identifying infectious organisms in post-transplant opportunistic infections.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man presents with an 8-month history of chronic diarrhea. Barium investigation shows loss of haustrations. Based on these findings, what is the diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ulcerative colitis

 

The combination of 8-month history of chronic diarrhea and loss of haustrations on barium study is characteristic of ulcerative colitis. Loss of haustrations creates the classic "lead pipe" appearance of the colon on barium enema, which is pathognomonic for ulcerative colitis. 

 

This finding indicates chronic inflammation that has led to loss of the normal colonic haustral folds. Ulcerative colitis typically presents with chronic bloody diarrhea and involves the colon in a continuous pattern starting from the rectum. The 8-month duration is consistent with the chronic nature of inflammatory bowel disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pseudomembranous enterocolitis: This condition is caused by Clostridium difficile and requires a history of antibiotic exposure. It typically presents acutely rather than with an 8-month chronic history. The patient would need recent antibiotic use to develop C. difficile-associated disease, and the chronic nature of symptoms makes this diagnosis unlikely.

 

Option C. Crohn's disease: While Crohn's disease can involve the colon, it most commonly affects the terminal ileum and demonstrates skip lesions rather than continuous involvement. Pure colonic involvement with loss of haustrations is more characteristic of ulcerative colitis. Crohn's disease typically shows a "garden hose" appearance rather than the "lead pipe" sign.

 

Option D. Intestinal TB: This condition predominantly affects the terminal ileum and ileocecal region, similar to Crohn's disease. It rarely causes the characteristic loss of haustrations seen throughout the colon that is typical of ulcerative colitis. Intestinal TB would not typically present with this specific radiological finding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Loss of haustrations on barium study creating a "lead pipe" appearance is pathognomonic for ulcerative colitis.

 

IBD -

questions.text:
Which of the following findings are typically associated with glomerular hematuria? (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. Brown urine
  2. Dysuria absent
  3. Crystals in urine
  4. Edema is rare
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A, B

 

Glomerular hematuria has specific characteristics that help differentiate it from non-glomerular causes:

 

A. Brown urine: Brown/cola-colored urine is typical of glomerular hematuria due to the presence of RBCs.

 

B. Dysuria absent: Absence of dysuria is characteristic, as there is no urinary tract inflammation or infection.

 

These findings together strongly suggest glomerular origin of hematuria.

 

Other Options:

 

C. Crystals in urine: Incorrect. Crystalluria is not a feature of glomerular hematuria. Instead, findings like dysmorphic RBCs, acanthocytes, or RBC casts are characteristic.

 

D. Edema is rare: Incorrect. Edema is common in glomerular diseases, whether nephritic or nephrotic, due to:

 

  • Loss of albumin leading to decreased oncotic pressure
  • Activation of the renin-angiotensin system
  • Underlying inflammatory processes

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glomerular hematuria includes brown/cola-colored urine and absence of dysuria, while presence of edema and absence of urinary crystals are other important characteristics.

questions.text: Features of MEN2B are all except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Parathyroid hyperplasia

 

MEN2B syndrome is characterized by a distinct set of clinical features known as the "4 M's":

 

  1. Marfanoid body habitus
  2. Mucosal neuromas
  3. Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC)
  4. Megacolon (Hirschsprung disease)

 

Additionally, pheochromocytoma is also a feature of MEN2B. The syndrome is caused by mutations in the RET proto-oncogene located on chromosome 10.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parathyroid hyperplasia is NOT a component of MEN2B syndrome, while the characteristic features include medullary thyroid carcinoma, mucosal neuromas, marfanoid habitus, and megacolon (the 4 M's).

questions.text: A tall male presents with absent pubic and axillary hair, infantile genitalia, high LH and FSH levels with XXY karyotype. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Klinefelter's syndrome

 

Klinefelter's syndrome is characterized by the presence of an extra X chromosome (47,XXY karyotype).

 

Patients present with hypogonadism (testicular atrophy), reduced secondary sexual characteristic, often grow taller and have more body hair, but without male pattern baldness. They may also develop gynecomastia due to an imbalance of testosterone and estrogen. Due to insufficient testosterone production, LH and FSH levels are elevated, resulting in hypergonadotropic hypogonadism. The high LH and FSH levels are a consequence of low testosterone feedback.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vanishing testis syndrome: Typically presents with normal male karyotype (46,XY).

 

Option C. Noonan syndrome: Presents with features similar to Turner syndrome but normal male karyotype.

 

Option D. Adrenal hyperplasia: Presents with ambiguous genitalia and other features but not associated with XXY karyotype.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Klinefelter's syndrome is characterized by tall stature, hypogonadism, and 47,XXY karyotype.

questions.text: Which of the following autoantibody isotypes is involved in the pathogenesis of Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (AIDP)? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IgG

 

Explanation:

 

Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (AIDP) is the most common form of Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS). The pathogenesis of AIDP involves autoimmune mechanisms where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks the peripheral nerves. This autoimmune response primarily involves the production of IgG antibodies against gangliosides present on the nerve membranes.

 

IgG antibodies are significant in the diagnosis and monitoring of Guillain-Barré Syndrome, and tests for ganglioside antibodies (such as anti-GM1 IgG) are commonly ordered in clinical settings to support the diagnosis.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. IgA: IgA is primarily involved in mucosal immunity and is not a key player in the pathogenesis of AIDP.

 

Option C. IgM: Although IgM antibodies are involved in initial immune responses, they are not primarily associated with AIDP pathogenesis.

 

Option D. IgE: IgE is associated with allergic reactions and parasitic infections, not with the autoimmune processes seen in AIDP.

 

Educational Objectives

 

IgG antibodies are involved in the pathogenesis of Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (AIDP), which is the most common form of Guillain-Barré Syndrome.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents to the OPD with bilateral swelling of lower limbs. On examination, there is elevated JVP, hepatomegaly, and ascites. What is your provisional diagnosis? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cardiac failure

 

The patient presents with symptoms and signs that are consistent with cardiac failure (congestive heart failure):

 

  • Bilateral swelling of lower limbs: Suggestive of peripheral edema, common in heart failure.
  • Elevated JVP (Jugular Venous Pressure): Indicates increased central venous pressure, often seen in right-sided heart failure.
  • Hepatomegaly: Enlargement of the liver due to congestion, often a sign of right-sided heart failure.
  • Ascites: Accumulation of fluid in the peritoneal cavity, which can occur in both cardiac and hepatic failure but is more indicative of cardiac failure in the absence of jaundice or other liver failure signs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Renal failure: Can cause peripheral edema but does not typically present with elevated JVP, hepatomegaly, and ascites in this manner.

 

Option C. Brain injury: Does not present with these systemic symptoms.

 

Option D. Hepatic failure: While it can cause ascites and hepatomegaly, it would also present with jaundice and other liver-related symptoms, which are not mentioned in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cardiac failure (congestive heart failure) often presents with elevated JVP, peripheral edema, hepatomegaly, and ascites, distinguishing it from other conditions like hepatic or renal failure.

questions.text: Auenbruggerâ€™s sign is seen in: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pericardial Effusion

 

Explanation:

 

Auenbrugger's sign refers to dullness in the left posterior lung field (at the base) that is seen in patients with large pericardial effusions. This is also known as Ewart's sign. When the pericardium expands due to fluid accumulation, it causes minicollapse and dullness in the left posterior lung field, which can be detected on percussion examination. This physical finding is characteristic of significant pericardial effusions.

 

 Other Options: 

 

Option B. Constrictive Pericarditis: Constrictive pericarditis presents with signs of right heart failure, increased JVP with prominent x and y descent, pericardial knock, and Kussmaul's sign (no respiratory variation of JVP). Auenbrugger's sign is not a feature of constrictive pericarditis.

 

Option C. Aortic Regurgitation: Aortic regurgitation typically presents with wide pulse pressure, diastolic murmur, and signs of left ventricular volume overload. Auenbrugger's sign is not associated with this valvular condition.

 

Option D. Mitral Stenosis: Mitral stenosis typically presents with symptoms of pulmonary congestion, a diastolic murmur, and possible atrial fibrillation. Auenbrugger's sign is not a feature of mitral stenosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Auenbrugger's sign (also known as Ewart's sign) is a physical finding characterized by dullness in the left posterior lung field due to compression by an enlarged pericardium in patients with large pericardial effusions.

choices.text: Pulmonary arterial hypertension

questions.text: A patient presents with dyspnea and distended neck veins that increase on inspiration. There is no murmur. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Constrictive pericarditis

 

The key clinical feature in this scenario is Kussmaul's sign, which is the paradoxical increase in jugular venous pressure (JVP) during inspiration. This is indicative of conditions that impede the normal inspiratory decrease in JVP, such as constrictive pericarditis.

 

Key Features of Constrictive Pericarditis:

 

  • Kussmaul's Sign: Lack of normal inspiratory decrease in JVP, or paradoxical increase, due to rigid pericardium that limits cardiac filling.
  • Dyspnea: Common due to impaired filling of the heart.
  • Absence of Murmur: Distinguishes it from valvular heart diseases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aortic regurgitation: Aortic regurgitation typically presents with a diastolic murmur and does not cause Kussmaul's sign.

 

Option C. Tricuspid stenosis: Tricuspid stenosis can cause elevated JVP, but it is usually associated with a diastolic murmur.

 

Option D. Pulmonary arterial hypertension: Pulmonary arterial hypertension can cause elevated JVP, but it is not typically associated with Kussmaul's sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kussmaul's sign, an increase in JVP on inspiration, is indicative of constrictive pericarditis. It is not associated with murmurs or primary valvular heart diseases.

choices.text: Hyaline membrane disease
Alpha 1 anti-trypsin deficiency

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presented with recurrent respiratory infections with thickened sputum. CXR showed bronchial wall thickening. He has been suffering from steatorrhea since birth. Which of the following is the first differential diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cystic fibrosis

 

Cystic fibrosis (CF) is a genetic disorder that leads to thick, sticky mucus production, affecting the lungs and digestive system. The key features in this case are recurrent respiratory infections, thickened sputum, bronchial wall thickening seen on CXR, and steatorrhea since birth.

 

Key Features of Cystic Fibrosis:

 

  • Recurrent Respiratory Infections: Due to thick mucus obstructing airways and predisposing to infections.
  • Thickened Sputum: A hallmark of CF due to mucus gland dysfunction.
  • Bronchial Wall Thickening: Visible on CXR, indicative of chronic respiratory disease.
  • Steatorrhea: Due to pancreatic insufficiency leading to fat malabsorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyaline membrane disease: This typically presents in neonates with respiratory distress syndrome, not in a 5-year-old with chronic symptoms.

 

Option C. Alpha 1 anti-trypsin deficiency: This condition can cause emphysema and liver disease, but it does not typically present with steatorrhea or bronchiectasis in early childhood.

 

Option D. Malabsorption syndrome: While this explains steatorrhea, it does not account for the respiratory symptoms and bronchiectasis seen in CF.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cystic fibrosis should be the first differential diagnosis in children with recurrent respiratory infections, thickened sputum, bronchial wall thickening on CXR, and steatorrhea since birth.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to you with features of anemia, fever, and recurrent nose bleeds. On examination there is hepatosplenomegaly, Lab investigations revealed: Hb = 6g/dL, TLC count = 40,000/ cu.mm with 10% blasts and platelet count = 12,000/cu.mm. On further investigation, t(8;21) was detected in the blasts. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute myeloblastic leukemia (AML)

 

The presence of anemia, hepatosplenomegaly, blasts in the blood (<20%), and the t(8;21) translocation is indicative of AML.

 

Typically, the diagnosis of AML requires a blast count greater than 20; However, if a signature cytogenetic abnormality, such as t(8,21), is present, a diagnosis of AML can be made even if the blast count is less than 20%.

 

Other key cytogenetic changes indicative of AML include:

 

  • t(15;17): This translocation results in the PML-RARA fusion protein.
  • Inversion 16 (or t(16;16)): Known as inversion 16 or CBF (core binding factor) leukemia.

 

These 3 signature cytogenetic abnormalities are so characteristic of AML that their presence alone can confirm the diagnosis, bypassing the need for a high blast count.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL): Typically presents in children and does not commonly show t(8;21).

 

Option C. Preleukemia: Not a definitive diagnosis with these findings.

 

Option D. Aleukemic leukemia: Refers to leukemia without blasts in the peripheral blood, which is not the case here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

AML is suggested by anemia, hepatosplenomegaly, blasts in blood, and the t(8;21) translocation.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presented with a 1-week history of yellow skin and sclerae but is otherwise asymptomatic. He gives a history of viral infection for 10 days which resolved 2 days back. There is a history of a similar episode of icterus 2 years back for a period of 2 weeks. The current serum bilirubin is 2.4 mg/ dL, unconjugated bilirubin 2.1mg/dl, conjugated bilirubin is 0.3mg/dl, Serum AST and ALT levels are normal. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gilbert syndrome

 

Gilbert syndrome is characterized by intermittent jaundice with elevated unconjugated bilirubin levels and normal liver enzyme levels, often triggered by stress or illness. The patient’s history of similar episodes and current lab findings fit the profile of Gilbert syndrome.

 

Gilbert syndrome is a benign condition characterized by mild elevations in unconjugated bilirubin, often occurring during periods of stress such as dehydration, fasting, surgery, or viral illness. Patients are typically asymptomatic, and the bilirubin elevation is usually transient and accompanied by normal liver enzymes and imaging. Viral markers are negative, and the condition is often discovered incidentally. The bilirubin levels do not exceed 3 milligrams per deciliter. Gilbert syndrome requires no treatment and is a common, harmless condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dubin-Johnson syndrome: Typically shows conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

 

Option B. Criggler-Najar type 1 syndrome: Severe form with persistent high unconjugated bilirubin levels from birth. the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase (UGT1A1) activity is essentially zero. This complete lack of enzyme activity leads to severe jaundice from birth. Liver transplantation is often necessary for survival, as the condition is fatal if untreated.

 

Option D. Rotor Syndrome: Similar to Dubin-Johnson but without liver pigmentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gilbert syndrome causes intermittent jaundice with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia and normal liver enzymes.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of depression was initially being treated with amitriptyline, but his symptoms were not adequately controlled. His medication regimen was changed to include an MAO inhibitor and sertraline. Shortly after this, he developed agitation and seizures. On examination, he had marked hyperreflexia and tremors. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cyproheptadine

 

The patient is presenting with symptoms of serotonin syndrome, a potentially life-threatening condition caused by excessive serotonin levels in the brain. This is likely due to the combination of an MAO inhibitor and sertraline, both of which can increase serotonin levels. Cyproheptadine is a serotonin antagonist that can help block the effects of excessive serotonin, making it the most appropriate treatment in this case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Flumazenil: Flumazenil is a benzodiazepine antagonist used to reverse the effects of benzodiazepine overdose. It is not indicated in serotonin syndrome.

 

Option C. L-carnitine: L-carnitine is an amino acid derivative that plays a role in energy metabolism. It has no role in the treatment of serotonin syndrome.

 

Option D. Leucovorin: Leucovorin is a form of folic acid used to reduce the toxicity of certain chemotherapy drugs. It has no role in the treatment of serotonin syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Combining MAO inhibitors and serotonergic medications like sertraline can lead to serotonin syndrome, a potentially life-threatening condition. Cyproheptadine is the drug of choice for treating serotonin syndrome.

questions.text: A child presents with anemia, neutropenia, and depigmentation of hair and nails. Which of the following deficiencies is most likely associated with this presentation? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Copper

 

Copper deficiency can lead to a range of symptoms, including those mentioned in the question:

 

  • Anemia: Copper is essential for iron absorption and red blood cell production. Copper deficiency can result in iron-deficiency anemia or other types of anemia, leading to fatigue and weakness.
  • Neutropenia: Copper plays a role in immune function. Deficiency can impair the production of white blood cells, including neutrophils, increasing susceptibility to infections.
  • Depigmentation: Copper is involved in melanin production, the pigment responsible for hair and nail color. Copper deficiency can cause hair and nails to lose their color.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Iron deficiency: While iron deficiency also causes anemia, it doesn't typically lead to neutropenia or depigmentation.

 

Option C. Fluoride deficiency: Fluoride is primarily associated with dental health. Its deficiency wouldn't cause the symptoms described in the question.

 

Option D. Zinc deficiency: Zinc deficiency can affect skin health and immune function, but it's more likely to present with growth retardation, delayed sexual maturation, and skin lesions rather than the specific combination of symptoms mentioned.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Copper deficiency can present with a triad of anemia, neutropenia, and depigmentation of hair and nails.

 

Note: Menkes disease, a rare genetic disorder affecting copper transport, is associated with these symptoms and characteristic "kinky hair."

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with a history of recurrent sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and chronic cough. He also mentions that he has had several ear infections and episodes of pneumonia over the past few years. On physical examination, you note digital clubbing. A chest X-ray is obtained. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kartagener syndrome

 

Kartagener syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the triad of situs inversus (reversal of internal organs), chronic sinusitis, and bronchiectasis. The presence of dextrocardia  and the fundic gas bubble on the right side of the abdomen in the chest X-ray strongly suggest situs inversus. The patient's history of recurrent sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and chronic cough further supports the diagnosis of Kartagener syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cystic fibrosis: Cystic fibrosis is a genetic disorder that primarily affects the lungs and digestive system. While it can cause recurrent respiratory infections, it is not associated with situs inversus or dextrocardia.

 

Option C. DiGeorge syndrome: DiGeorge syndrome is a genetic disorder that affects the development of several body systems, including the immune system and the heart. It is not associated with situs inversus, bronchiectasis, or chronic sinusitis.  

 

Option D. Down syndrome: Down syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 21. It is not associated with situs inversus, bronchiectasis, or chronic sinusitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kartagener syndrome is characterized by the triad of situs inversus, chronic sinusitis, and bronchiectasis.

choices.text: IV Digoxin can be used for ventricular rate control.
Direct oral anticoagulants to be given.
Cardioversion should be done in hemodynamically unstable patients.
Beta blockers are given if the patient has decompensated heart failure and intolerant to calcium channel blockers.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man with a history of hypertension presents with shortness of breath and palpitations. On examination, he has an irregularly irregular pulse with bilateral basal crackles. An ECG shows a ventricular response of 110/min. Which of the following statements is incorrect? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Beta blockers are given if the patient has decompensated heart failure and intolerant to calcium channel blockers

 

This statement is incorrect because beta blockers are not recommended in patients with decompensated heart failure. Beta blockers are negative inotropic agents, meaning they decrease the force of the heart's contractions. In a patient with decompensated heart failure, the heart is already struggling to pump blood effectively and further reducing its contractility can worsen the condition. The first-line treatment for rate control in atrial fibrillation with decompensated heart failure is typically calcium channel blockers or digoxin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV Digoxin can be used for ventricular rate control: This statement is correct. Digoxin is often used for rate control in atrial fibrillation, especially in patients with heart failure. It works by slowing the conduction of electrical signals through the atrioventricular (AV) node, thereby reducing the heart rate.

 

Option B. Direct oral anticoagulants to be given: This statement is generally correct. Direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) are preferred over warfarin for stroke prevention in patients with non-valvular atrial fibrillation unless there are specific contraindications such as moderate to severe mitral stenosis or a mechanical heart valve.

 

Option C. Cardioversion should be done in hemodynamically unstable patients: This statement is correct. Cardioversion, which is the process of restoring a normal heart rhythm using electrical or pharmacological means, is indicated in patients with atrial fibrillation who are hemodynamically unstable. Hemodynamic instability refers to a state where the heart is unable to pump enough blood to meet the body's needs, leading to symptoms such as low blood pressure, shortness of breath, and confusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta blockers should be avoided in patients with decompensated heart failure due to their negative inotropic effects.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with complaints of weakness and generalized fatigue. The peripheral smear shows microcytic hypochromic RBCs. Her serum iron is decreased and has increased RDW. Her MCV and MCH were also low, and TIBC was high. What would her serum transferrin saturation be? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reduced

 

The clinical presentation and lab findings are consistent with iron deficiency anemia. In iron deficiency anemia:

 

  • Serum iron levels are low as the body lacks sufficient iron.
  • TIBC (Total Iron Binding Capacity) is high as the body tries to compensate by increasing its capacity to bind iron.
  • Transferrin saturation is the percentage of transferrin (an iron-transport protein) that is saturated with iron. It is calculated as (Serum Iron / TIBC) x 100.
  • Since serum iron is low and TIBC is high, the transferrin saturation will be reduced. Typically, in iron deficiency anemia, transferrin saturation is less than 20%.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased: This is incorrect.

 

Option C. Equivocal: This is incorrect.

 

Option D. Cannot be determined: This is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In iron deficiency anemia, transferrin saturation is reduced (typically less than 20%) due to low serum iron and high TIBC.

questions.text: A young athlete was diagnosed to have HOCM and has a harsh ejection systolic murmur. Which of the following maneuvers would most likely increase the intensity of the murmur? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Valsalva maneuver

 

The intensity of the murmur in hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM) is directly related to the degree of left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction. The Valsalva maneuver decreases preload (the amount of blood returning to the heart), which in turn, increases the LVOT obstruction and intensifies the murmur.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isometric Hand grip: This maneuver increases afterload (the resistance the heart pumps against), which decreases LVOT obstruction and reduces the intensity of the murmur.

 

Option C. Squatting: Squatting increases preload, leading to a decrease in LVOT obstruction and a reduction in the murmur's intensity.

 

Option D. Leaning forward: This maneuver has no significant effect on the hemodynamics of HOCM and thus does not alter the murmur's intensity. It can, however, accentuate the murmur in aortic stenosis by bringing the aortic valve closer to the chest wall.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In HOCM, maneuvers that decrease preload (like the Valsalva maneuver) will increase the intensity of the murmur, while those that increase preload or afterload will decrease it.

questions.text: A 25-year-old P1L1 woman is planning for her second child. She has been recently diagnosed with Grave's disease. Which of the following is the antithyroid drug to be used in early gestation? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Propylthiouracil

 

Propylthiouracil (PTU) is preferred during the first trimester of pregnancy due to the risk of teratogenic effects from methimazole and carbimazole, such as aplasia cutis.

 

Methimazole or carbimazole can be used in the second and third trimesters.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Methimazole and C. Carbimazole: Not preferred in the first trimester due to teratogenic risks.

 

Option D. Radioactive Iodine: Absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy & lactation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Propylthiouracil is the preferred antithyroid drug during early gestation (first trimester).

choices.text: Sickle cell anemia
Von Willebrand disease type 1

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy complains of multiple episodes of acute severe pain in his fingers and toes which resolves on its own for the past 1 year. Which of the following conditions is he most likely suffering from? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Sickle cell anemia

 

The symptoms described in the question—acute severe pain episodes in the fingers and toes—are characteristic of vaso-occlusive crises, which are a hallmark of sickle cell anemia. These episodes are caused by sickle-shaped red blood cells that obstruct blood flow in small blood vessels, leading to ischemic pain. This condition results from a mutation leading to the production of hemoglobin S, which polymerizes under low oxygen conditions, distorting the red blood cells into a sickle shape.

 

 

  • HbF, ↑ WBC, LDH is predictive of clinical severity.
  • Target Hb < 10g/dL (To minimize risk of Sickling episodes due to high viscosity).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alpha-thalassemia: This condition involves a deficiency in the production of alpha globin chains but does not typically manifest with acute pain episodes like sickle cell anemia.

 

Option B. Beta-thalassemia: Like alpha-thalassemia, this involves a problem with globin chain production (beta chains in this case) and also does not typically present with acute pain episodes.

 

Option D. Von Willebrand disease type 1: This is a bleeding disorder, not a hemoglobinopathy, characterized by a qualitative or quantitative deficiency of von Willebrand factor, which helps with blood clotting. It would more commonly present with symptoms related to bleeding rather than ischemic pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sickle cell anemia should be suspected in patients who present with episodic acute pain in the extremities, a symptom commonly resulting from vaso-occlusive crises due to abnormal sickle-shaped red blood cells blocking blood flow.

 

Reference - Harrison 21 /Hemoglobinopathies/Chapter 98

questions.text: A man presents with a history of hematemesis involving approximately 500 ml of blood. On examination, his spleen is palpable 5 cm below the left costal margin. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Portal Hypertension

 

The patient presents with hematemesis (vomiting blood) and splenomegaly (enlarged spleen palpable 5 cm below the costal margin). These two findings strongly suggest portal hypertension as the most likely diagnosis. Portal hypertension is defined as an elevation of hepatic venous pressure gradient >5 mmHg and is directly responsible for variceal hemorrhage, a major complication that can present with hematemesis. The combination of splenomegaly and upper GI bleeding in the form of hematemesis is characteristic of portal hypertension.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Isolated splenic vein thrombosis: While this can cause localized portal hypertension with splenomegaly, it typically causes gastric rather than esophageal varices. The pattern of bleeding would be different, and it's much less common than generalized portal hypertension.

 

Option C. Drug-induced gastritis: This can cause hematemesis but doesn't explain the significant splenomegaly. Gastritis alone would not cause spleen enlargement of this magnitude (5 cm below costal margin).

 

Option D. Mallory-Weiss tear: This is a mucosal laceration at the gastroesophageal junction typically occurring after forceful vomiting. While it can cause hematemesis, it would not explain the splenomegaly, which is a key finding in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of significant hematemesis and splenomegaly strongly suggests portal hypertension with variceal bleeding, which is one of the major life-threatening complications of cirrhosis requiring prompt management.

questions.text: A patient stopped alcohol 3 days ago, presented with irritability, altered sensorium, and visual hallucinations. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Delirium Tremens

 

Delirium Tremens (DT) is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal that typically occurs 48-72 hours after the last drink. It is characterized by:

 

  • Autonomic instability (e.g., tachycardia, hypertension, hyperthermia)
  • Severe agitation and irritability
  • Altered sensorium (e.g., confusion, delirium)
  • Visual and auditory hallucinations

 

DT is a medical emergency with high morbidity and mortality if not treated promptly.

 

The treatment of choice is benzodiazepines, which help to control agitation and prevent complications such as seizures. Long-acting benzodiazepines like diazepam are preferred unless there is liver dysfunction, in which case shorter-acting agents like lorazepam or oxazepam are used.

 

Special Considerations for Liver Impairment:

 

  • Cirrhosis or Severe Liver Failure: In patients with compromised liver function, the metabolism of drugs, particularly those processed by the liver, can be significantly impaired.
  • Short-Acting Drugs: Lorazepam is recommended as it is less reliant on hepatic oxidation and more on glucuronidation, which is relatively preserved in liver disease.
  • Oxazepam is also suggested as it undergoes direct conjugation in the liver without the need for extensive metabolism, making it safer for patients with severe liver impairment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wernickeâ€™s Encephalopathy: Wernickeâ€™s Encephalopathy is caused by thiamine deficiency and presents with a triad of ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and confusion. It does not typically present with hallucinations or irritability.

 

Option C. Korsakoff Psychosis: Korsakoff Psychosis is a chronic condition resulting from untreated Wernickeâ€™s Encephalopathy, characterized by severe memory impairment/ amnesia and confabulation. It does not present acutely and lacks the autonomic instability seen in DT.

 

Option D. Alcohol Withdrawal Seizures: Alcohol withdrawal seizures typically occur within 6-48 hours after the last drink and present as generalized tonic-clonic seizures (GTCS). They do not present with the prolonged altered sensorium or hallucinations characteristic of DT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Delirium Tremens is a severe alcohol withdrawal syndrome occurring 48-72 hours after cessation of alcohol intake, characterized by autonomic instability, severe agitation, altered sensorium, and hallucinations. It requires immediate treatment with benzodiazepines to manage symptoms and prevent complications.

questions.text: A female patient with infertility presents with galactorrhea. Evaluation reveals a 7mm prolactinoma. She is worried about her conception chances. What is the appropriate drug in this situation? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Bromocriptine

 

Explanation:

 

The choice of dopamine agonist therapy for hyperprolactinemia in patients desiring fertility remains somewhat controversial. Advanced textbooks such as "Speroff's Clinical Gynecologic Endocrinology and Infertility" clearly highlight that cabergoline has greater potency, fewer side effects, better tolerability, and convenient dosing compared to bromocriptine, leading to its general preference for prolactinoma treatment.

 

However, Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine (21st Edition) explicitly mentions:

 

â€œBecause cabergoline is long-acting with a high Dâ‚‚-receptor affinity, it is not recommended for use in women when fertility is desired.â€

 

Considering the context of Indian postgraduate entrance examinations, it is advisable to adhere to Harrison's recommendations. Therefore, although cabergoline is generally considered superior, bromocriptine is the safer and recommended answer for this specific examination scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cabergoline: Although generally preferred for routine prolactinoma management, it is explicitly not recommended during conception planning as per Harrisonâ€™s.

 

Option C. Octreotide: A somatostatin analog indicated exclusively for GH-secreting tumors, not prolactinoma.

 

Option D. Pegvisomant: A GH receptor antagonist used specifically in acromegaly, with no role in prolactinoma or fertility management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For Indian PG entrance examinations, bromocriptine remains the recommended first-line treatment in women with microprolactinoma who desire fertility, despite cabergolineâ€™s clinical advantages, based on guidelines explicitly mentioned in Harrisonâ€™s Principles of Internal Medicine.

choices.text: Stop oral methotrexate and start parenteral methotrexate
Add sulfasalazine and hydroxychloroquine
Continue corticosteroids and methotrexate
Start only anti-TNF alpha agents

questions.text: A patient with rheumatoid arthritis is being treated with methotrexate and low-dose corticosteroids for the past 4 months. However, the disease is still progressing. What would be your recommendation for the further management of this patient? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Add sulfasalazine and hydroxychloroquine

 

Adding sulfasalazine and hydroxychloroquine to the treatment regimen for a patient with rheumatoid arthritis who is not responding adequately to methotrexate and low-dose corticosteroids is a sound strategy. This approach follows the principle of combining different disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) to achieve better disease control. Both sulfasalazine and hydroxychloroquine are DMARDs that work by different mechanisms to reduce inflammation and slow disease progression in rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stop oral methotrexate and start parenteral methotrexate: While switching to parenteral administration can increase the effectiveness of methotrexate for some patients, it might not be sufficient alone if the disease is still progressing.

 

Option C. Continue corticosteroids and methotrexate: Continuing the same treatment without modification is not advisable if the disease is actively progressing, as this indicates that the current regimen is insufficient.

 

Option D. Start only anti-TNF alpha agents: While anti-TNF agents are effective for many patients, they are typically used after trying combination DMARD therapy, especially in cases not severe enough to warrant immediate biologic therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a patient with rheumatoid arthritis does not respond adequately to initial therapy with methotrexate and corticosteroids, the addition of other DMARDs such as sulfasalazine and hydroxychloroquine can be beneficial.

 

Drugs:

 

  • Methotrexate: Start 10mg/week → max 25mg/week along with Folic acid twice/week
  • Check ocular fundus before HCQ initiation
  • Leflunomide, sulfasalazine other group of drugs.
  • Sulfasalazine is safe in pregnancy !!
  • Symptomatic relief with NSAID and short course corticosteroids.

 

Reference - Harrison/Rheumatoid arthritis/ Chap 358

questions.text: A patient presents with elevated bilirubin levels. Urine urobilinogen is absent, but urine bilirubin is present. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Obstructive jaundice

 

Explanation:

 

The pattern of laboratory findings with elevated bilirubin levels, presence of bilirubin in urine, and absence of urobilinogen in urine is characteristic of obstructive (cholestatic) jaundice. In obstructive jaundice, conjugated bilirubin cannot be excreted into the intestine due to biliary obstruction. This conjugated hyperbilirubinemia results in spillage of water-soluble conjugated bilirubin into urine (bilirubinuria). Since bilirubin cannot reach the intestine, there is no formation of urobilinogen by intestinal bacteria, resulting in absent urinary urobilinogen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatitis: While hepatitis can cause elevated bilirubin, it typically has a mixed pattern with both direct and indirect bilirubin elevation. In hepatitis, urobilinogen would be present or elevated in urine due to continued, albeit reduced, flow of bilirubin to the intestines where it is converted to urobilinogen.

 

Option B. Hemolytic jaundice: In hemolytic jaundice, there is unconjugated (indirect) hyperbilirubinemia due to excessive destruction of red blood cells. Since unconjugated bilirubin is not water-soluble, it cannot appear in urine. Urobilinogen would be increased, not absent, due to increased bilirubin load reaching the intestines.

 

Option D. Gilbert's syndrome: This is characterized by mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. As with hemolytic jaundice, unconjugated bilirubin does not appear in urine. Additionally, urobilinogen would be normal or slightly increased in Gilbert's syndrome, not absent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key diagnostic pattern for obstructive jaundice is the presence of conjugated hyperbilirubinemia leading to bilirubinuria with absent urinary urobilinogen due to blockage of bilirubin flow into the intestine.
